reviewText:
Before the review, I want to exclaim:
BUY COMMANDOS 2 IF YOU HAVE NEVER PLAYED ANY OF THE COMMANDOS GAMES.
Also, this game usually costs 1 $ or € throughout the Steam sales.

I remember when I was younger playing this game and how fun it was. Controlling commandos behind enemy lines. Stealth. Tactics. The experience was amazing and I am elated right now to play this game again.

The game's charm is in figuring out enemy's patterns, observing the environment, planning tactics and then carrying it all out. It is hard, but addicting and rewarding in the end. A simple act of throwing cigarette packs and then knocking out a soldier and tying him up, booby-trapping, throwing a bomb at a group of soldiers or disguising as an officer with a spy is satisfying.

The game is a little hard to get into at first, but after you really pass the two training levels, you are essentially ready to go.
VERY USEFUL TO KNOW: CTRL-S and CTRL-L for quicksave and quickload.

It was also released in 2002 so the game looks rough and doesn't support widescreen natively. To remedy this, you can pick up executables that fix this (https://sites.google.com/site/xbootx/home/commandos2), although very high resolutions might cause graphical glitches. There is also a mod called Destination Paris (http://commandoshq.net/c2dp_dloads.php) that makes the game even more challenging.

Commandos 2 is my favorite game in the whole series and I recommend it to Commandos newcomers; as Behind Enemy Lines and Beyond the Call of Duty are too unforgiving (I haven't played Commandos 3 yet, but it's apparently not as up to par). Alternatively, you can try Desperados if you're more into Wild West or Robin Hood: The Legend of Sherwood if you're into Middle Ages.

Commandos 2 is one of few examples, where a sequel of the game turns out at least just as good, if not better, then the original idea.
To be clear: if there is a single flaw of Commandos 2, compared to Commandos 1, it is low difficulty level.

In a nutshell:
the game is isometric sneaker strategy / logical game in real time,
World War 2 themed, British commandos fight against III Reich and ... Japan,
consists of ten regular missions, nine bonus missions (+1 regular mission 'bonus phase'), and two trainings,
roughly 20-40 hours to beat.
So what it is all about? The key idea remains the same:
player has 1-8 (usually 3-5) commandos to control

a dirty job guy aka Green Beret, stealth and melee combat expert,

reviewText:
Short version: 91%Better graphics, huge maps, simplified controls and less strict game mechanics were a great recipe for success for Commandos 2, even if the more hardcore fans were a bit disappointed with the more monotonous gameplay and low difficulty.

Long version:Commandos 2: Men of Courage was the most successful entry of this series of isometric strategy/stealth World War II games about a small group of international soldiers sent behind enemy lines.

The game features ten missions (plus ten bonus levels) with great map size and large variety in design and objectives. The levels have a more cinematic feel to them, thanks to replacing the short briefings with dialogues, and also adding small arcing plots.

The general goal of the game remained: sabotage Nazi and Japanese forces, which can mean anything from blowing up a submarine to saving some POWs.
To achieve this, you are usually required to get rid of all enemy soldiers on the map – mostly by stealth, but some segments require combat, and in some cases you even need to fend off invading forces. The latter ones don’t really fit into the game though, as they are more of a repetitive memory game that gets pretty boring pretty fast.

The commandos themselves received an overhaul. Everyone retained their unique abilities, but basic actions like driving, knocking out enemies, and carrying bodies can be done by anyone.
This was a double-edged sword. Many situations require team coordination, but this coordination mostly means throwing two packs of cigarettes to the floor and quickly hitting two soldiers on the head. This trick works for the majority of the game, leaving gameplay quite repetitive, especially when you need to do this on more than a hundred enemies.

If you can live with this repetitive nature, the great map design will more than make up for it, giving you a memorable and quite long game for very little money.

reviewText:
One of the best tactical stealth games ever made. Haven't played 3 yet but I can say that 2 is much better than 1. You control a selection of soldiers each with their own personality, abilities and traits. Each level is sort of a sandbox with lots of hidden weapons and utilities you can use to complete your objectives. The objectives are all very clearly defined with lots of maps and pictures in your intelligence folders along with the documentation of each tactic, ability and item in the game simply at the press of a button. I would recommend learning the hotkeys and to quicksave a lot, but make sure you don't do it the second you get shot at, as you might regret that.

The graphics are holding up very well since most of the levels is 2D with lots of detail. 3D models are small enough to not notice the limited polycount.

The program itself is clearly dated though as you can only use 4:3 resolutions, and you can only change the in game resolution (every time you hit ESC or watch a cutscene your res will change to the menu resolution for the time, then back again which is a pain with windowed mode since it always resets the position of the window). Check the pc gaming wiki on how to enable window mode (it is a simple cfg tweak, disables mouse scroll sadly). Be careful with the window mode as the game can and will crash 8/10 times you click outside of the game. Other than this it runs fine on W10 x64 without any compatibility issues.

reviewText:
One of the best Real time Strategy games ever made.
Instead of commanding armies, you have one to ten World war 2 commandos, each with various unique abilities.
Stealth in nature, it plays almost like an action puzzle game, having your men in the right position and using the right abilities, the game requires perfect timing for clean kills.
While the AI isn't particually stellar, it never breaks the game, and they can suprise you on occasion. (Careful with footprints in the snow)
One of the things you'll notice after a few hours of play is that some of your men are simply more useful than others. While some may have items or abilities required for mission success, you'll definitely use one or two over the others, for the majority of the game.

In terms of graphics, it still holds up after all these years, each character is small on the screen but quite detailed, and the environments are so beautiful and well crafted, it's clear that a lot of research was done to make the game, which leads me to the next point.

If you're a world war 2 buff, or you're just interested in that time period, you'll enjoy playing your part in history, destorying U-boats, assisting Ghurkas resist imperial japan, and decrypting the enigma code.

Plenty of missions, great stealth action, it's just good old nazi killing fun for the whole family.

reviewText:
A huge and incredible jump following the success of Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines - And still looks just as exceptional

We see a welcome return of much that made the first game amazing: A true David & Goliath situation where, using your wits and the skills of a handful of commandos, you must work your way through heavily-guarded encampments, cities and even Colditz Castle itself - eliminating enemy soldiers as you attempt to neutralise key targets, rescue captives and capture the enigma machine. Gratefully all of the commandos from the first game return, charming as ever, including a few extra faces. This goes way beyond point-and-click stealth - The game requires a lot of patience, careful planning and studying of enemy movements. For 10 missions (not counting bonus ones), there's a huge amount to do - so expect to divulge many hours into this... it's a beast!

There's a ton of new features and abilities too - including completely revamped graphics and a superb soundtrack, the biggie is that you can now enter (and operate) within buildings - bringing huge levels of new scope to the missions. Each Commando also now has an 'inventory' and can carry / exchange any item (even if they cannot necessarily use them) and there's much more this time around in terms of raiding boxes / cabinets for useful items or pinching them off some guards

The missions bring with them an exceptional variety too. Amongst the sneak-and-kill we're used to, the first night mission forces you to play without any killing. Another leaves you with just one Commando having to set free the rest of your companions, held captive in several different houses. You also get a number of 'defence' scenarios where you have to place your guys and a handful of friendly soldiers to defend against an attack force. It's varied and brings refreshing new elements to an already formidable game

I have two small gripes though. The first is that, compared to the original, it's not as difficult where you no longer have garrisons. Previously, patrols would start swarming the place if you set off the alarm - here, the consequence is less fatal. That's not to say the guards are any less dangerous, but you can sometimes ragequit a situation with a few well-aimed shots or explosives if you get fed up. The 'rooms' tend not to interact with each other much, so it splits up the levels into smaller easier-to-manage chunks

The second... Spike the rat (and a castaway with a trumpet). Come on... a specially trained rat that does backflips to distract enemy soldiers? You can get infinite uses, send it through doors and it pretty much distracts nearly any group... Talk about overpowered. It removed a lot of the challenge - not to mention being quite ridiculous

Truth be told though, that's nit-picking. It's an otherwise exceptional title which successfully manages to retain much of what made the first so ground-breaking, whilst valiantly bringing in a cavalcade of new features and dynamics. Superb work

The gameplay really good, if you ever met with trouble like a soldier that always looking at the entrance to a door that leads to your mission goal, the door is in his line of sight and if you get in his line of sight he will alert the other soldier, you can kill him but the other soldier has his line of sight on the soldier that you need to kill, thus rendering frontal attack useless. So how do you get pass him? The game provide many ways to do it, you can command your commando to disguise as the enemy and get him to provide distraction by talking to the other soldier, and then you command your other unit to attack the soldier that watching the door, or you can throw a cigerattes to distract the soldier out of the other soldier line of sight thus allowing you to attack him, or maybe there's another way to the mission goal and you should look for another way in.

The music is also really good, there's nothing else that i can say about the music. It's excellent.

Grapich wise it's still good for an old game, though sometimes the background blends with certain object, thus making it hard too click on that object. (The ladder on the top of the tower that located near the fueltanks in mission 3 kinda blends to the background making it hard too click) But nonetheless it's not a really big deal.

This game is a real recommend for those strategy games fans.

reviewText: Commandos 2: Men of Courage combine the brutally long gameplay of its predecessors with modernized graphics. The game, while still maintaining the long mission length, somehow manages to be easier than Commandos 1.  There is more leeway for mistakes and as result Commandos 2 is less masochistic than its predecessor. That doesn’t mean this game will be easy on beginners though, in fact the tutorial and first few mission should hurt your ego if you think this game will be a cake walk. The graphic, sound effects and musical score are all very nice and varied. However, the game severely fails when it comes to clarity of objectives and pathetically easy enemy takedown patterns. In some missions the objectives are borderline invisible, so you may have killed all the enemies on the map, but if you can’t find the one specific npc, you will never leave the map. Overall a good entry level and modern commandos game, imo the best of the series regardless of a few negatives.

This is one of the best classic games I ever played. Actually I played Commandos 2 on PS2 a lot, and I'm surprised when this game appeared on Steam Sale. The previous series are suck, trust me, after playing Commandos 2 you will say the exact same thing.

Commandos 2 is a strategy game where you command 2 or more commandos (the team) to infiltrate enemy base or sneak behind enemy lines to ruin their plan. The game took place on WWII that means you'll face the infamous nazis and japanese. To score a mission you'll need to play the game flawlessly, and that means avoid being detected at all times especially on Hard level.

You can knock an enemy unsonscious, tie them up, and throm them over the water or you can just stab them with Green Berret's knife to kill them silently. Don't wander around too much and make sure don't run like a crazy person because enemies will notice. You can also command Spy or Natasha to sneak pass the enemy ranks to steal some information, items or even you can just kill them with your commandos.

Overall, this is a great game. The graphics? Well, not much to say, it's not that great but I think this game has a great gameplay that you won't regret buying it. Haven't try the Commandos 3 yet but I heard the fans rather dissapointed and prefer the Commandos 2 over it.
